entry.title: Miner dilution attack on Bitcoin - is that something plausible?
entry.summary: A recent discussion on the bitcoin-dev mailing list has raised concerns about the possibility of a malicious actor acquiring a majority of hash power and using it to produce valid, but empty blocks. This scenario, known as the "empty block fallacy," could potentially disrupt the Bitcoin network by slowing down transaction processing and increasing confirmation times.The discussion on the mailing list included a detailed analysis of the potential impact of this scenario on the Bitcoin network. Some participants argued that the risk of a malicious actor acquiring a majority of hash power is low, while others emphasized the need for stronger security measures to prevent such an attack.The potential impact of the empty block fallacy on the Bitcoin network has been a topic of debate among researchers and developers for several years. The issue was first discussed in detail in a 2016 paper by Cornell University researchers, who found that the impact of the fallacy could be mitigated by implementing more efficient mining algorithms and improving network security.The debate over the empty block fallacy highlights the ongoing challenges facing the Bitcoin network as it continues to grow and evolve. While the network's decentralized architecture provides many benefits, it also makes it vulnerable to attacks from malicious actors. As a result, developers and researchers are working to develop new solutions and improve existing ones to ensure the long-term stability and security of the Bitcoin network.
